learning_objectives.objective: Define supply chain compromise and list the key components of the supply chain ecosystem (e.g., developers, manufacturers, acquirers, integrators).
Explain Cybersecurity Supply Chain Risk Management (C-SCRM) and common attack vectors such as typosquatting, malicious updates, and dependency confusion.
Identify potential supply chain risks in a given organizational scenario, mapping them to MITRE ATT&CK techniques like T1195.001 (Compromise Software Dependencies and Development Tools).
Compare and contrast software supply chain attacks (e.g., CI/CD pipeline compromise) versus hardware supply chain attacks (e.g., firmware tampering).
Critique the effectiveness of NIST SP 800-161 and SP 1305 frameworks for mitigating supply chain risks in a threat hunting context.
Design a threat hunting query (e.g., using Sigma or Splunk) to detect indicators of supply chain compromise, such as tampered artifacts or anomalous dependency downloads.
